user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of answer_unique_dyn_response:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
answer_unique_dyn_response (void *cls,
                            struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                            const char *url,
                            const char *method,
                            const char *version,
                            const char *upload_data,
                            size_t *upload_data_size,
                            void **req_cls)
{
  static int marker = 0;
  struct MHD_Response *r;
  enum MHD_Result ret;
  (void) cls;  /* Unused */
  (void) url; (void) version; /* Unused */
  (void) upload_data; (void) upload_data_size; /* Unused */

  if (NULL == *req_cls)
  {
    /* The fist call */
    *req_cls = (void *) ▮
    /* Do not send reply yet. No error. */
    return MHD_YES;
  }
  if ((0 != strcmp (method, MHD_HTTP_METHOD_GET)) &&
      (0 != strcmp (method, MHD_HTTP_METHOD_HEAD)))
    return MHD_NO; /* Unsupported method, close connection */

#if MHD_VERSION >= 0x00097701
  r = MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static (body_dyn_size,
                                              body_dyn);
#else  /* MHD_VERSION < 0x00097701 */
  r = MHD_create_response_from_buffer (body_dyn_size,
                                       (void *) body_dyn,
                                       MHD_RESPMEM_PERSISTENT);
#endif /* MHD_VERSION < 0x00097701 */
  ret = MHD_queue_response (connection, MHD_HTTP_OK, r);
  MHD_destroy_response (r);
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No function parameter is assigned to in this function. The MISRA rule prohibits modifying the pointer parameter itself; modifying the object pointed to is allowed. Examination of each pointer parameter shows only permitted uses:

- cls: only cast to void ((void) cls;) — no assignment to cls.
- connection: passed to other functions but not assigned to; the pointer itself is not modified.
- url, method, version, upload_data: only cast to void or read (method is compared via strcmp) — not reassigned.
- upload_data_size: cast to void ((void) upload_data_size;) — not modified.
- req_cls (void **): the code reads and writes *req_cls (NULL == *req_cls and *req_cls = (void *)&marker). Writing the object pointed to is allowed by the rule; the pointer parameter req_cls itself is not reassigned.

Other expressions (casts like (void *) body_dyn) concern non-parameter objects and do not modify any function parameter. Therefore there are no code fragments that violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 in the provided function.
